185637239.review:
Civilization: Beyond Earth est, selon moi, l'un des meilleurs jeux de la licence Civilization, voire des jeux de gestion-stratégie en général.

Si le gameplay est, de manière générale, très semblable à Civilization V, il y apporte également énormément d'éléments qui le rendent nettement plus intéressant, impliquant activement le joueur non seulement dans le développement de sa civilisation, mais également dans la manière dont se développent ses villes et bâtiments, son développement technologique, militaire, via les méchanismes de quêtes/évenements à choix et surtout, peut-être le plus gros point fort du jeu: Les affinités.

Le système des affinités, qui déterminent comment sa civilisation évolue et s'adapte au monde extraterrestre, est non seulement bien intégré, mais également véritablement agréable à explorer. Il permet, dans un seul jeu, d'avoir plusieurs manières de le jouer dans la plupart des aspects de Civilization, autant d'un point de vue militaire, social, démographique, industriel, ... Et tout ça, avec une patte graphique délicieuse.

Au-delà de ça, l'histoire et le lore du jeu sont également bien développés, le civilopédia, le "wiki" intégré au jeux civilizations, n'a jamais été aussi fourni et luxuriant, expliquant tout de la lente auto-destruction de l'humanité face au changement climatique jusqu'aux projets et ambitions des nations coloniales que l'on joue.

En bref, Civilization: Beyond Earth est une perle, et ce serait un rêve d'en voir une suite, ou même d'autres styles de jeu dérivé de son univers (un RPG serait purement et simplement incroyable, pour être honnête). Quoi qu'il en soit, je recommende chaudement.

185544367.review:
An under rated entry in the Civilization series that unfortunately didn't get the support it needed from the developers. The idea of a desperate mission to another planet to colonize it and save the species is a hell of a starter. Choosing what to bring to ensure your success was something that needed to be expanded on but wasn't at launch. Another problem was too many people made parallels to Alpha Centauri thinking it was a reboot of sorts and the devs didn't do enough to dissuade people from that idea.

It hasn't aged well, but I still think it's in my top 10.

185285127.review:
Despite being released four years after Civilization V, this game has less nations, smaller maps, worse balancing, and much fewer advanced settings options. 

The new "Affinity" system isn't interesting -- the game claims that the affinity you choose will not affect your play style, but what that really means is they are almost entirely interchangeable, serving only to give different skins to your units. Late game, you can expect to have high levels in all three of them, anyway. The Covert Ops system is mostly useless. Even with maxed out agents and stacking a ton of bonuses, mission success chances remain staggeringly low, and it is basically impossible to raise the intrigue level higher than 3.

The game is also really difficult, even compared to other Civ games. Expansion is agonizingly slow, enemy units are very tough, and resource tiles are sparse even when set to "Abundant". And all of that is on "normal" difficulty.

Also, the game crashes *very* frequently, which is what finally motivated me to write this review. Combine all of these flaws, and playing Beyond Earth is a slog. Go buy Civ V instead.

184520350.review:
I have been a fan of this franchise since the start, I remember playing the very first title on a super old system that had Windows XP and I have grown to love the franchise especially the 5th & 6th instalment.

Beyond Earth is a whole different take on the franchise, imagine colonizing other random planets and having to deal with the concept of creating a civilized empire among alien life forms. It’s an interesting and refreshingly different take but my lord is it a hard game to master.

You don’t have famous historical names to reference, having to remember the names of different colonies and its leaders can be tough. Having to navigate the overall complex skill/science tree is hectic and trying to understand what new mechanical systems there are to create and produce can be a struggle to.

It all feels so, ALIEN, indeed. As for the technical issues, I did have some issue running my game but as of this review on this date my game runs perfectly fine on my up-to-date Windows 10 platform. Initially I found that launching was failing but once I verified the integrity of the game files through STEAM, it was found to have been missing 1 crucial file, not sure what it was, but STEAM automatically downloaded the file that was missing and I was able to run my game just fine.

Overall, I recommend this game as a very different change of pace but with that said, the previous title still remains my favourite in the franchise thus far.

Recommended 7/10

184387319.review:
Can't tell ya what the "Mixed" review status is all about other than the fact that 2K launcher removal borked launch of the game for a few days. That was no issue for me, and now I'm playing what might be the best entry in the Civ series.

Cartoonish caricatures of worn-out historical figures? Nope. We got all new characters, realistically modeled. Doesn't matter that they don't have VAs. In fact, I think I like a silent world leader. Too many of them like to hear themselves talk, y'know? Anyway.

That, and the dynamic quests, make for your own storyline. Sucks that there's no custom leader creator, but at least I'm not playing as the same tired characters. It doesn't matter if Elizabeth I, Victoria and Eleanor were all different figures with wildly different personalities if there's no depth to the storytelling. That depth is here. I care about my colonists finding these weird aliens. I get to choose what path my civ takes, and that choice matters. Do I bait the little bastards to study them? Do I repel them with a sonic fence? What's gonna happen in either case? IDK yet! And I love it! :D

I normally recommend Civ's 2K-published offerings at 90% off only, because the pricing scheme for Civ VI sucks every kind of ball imaginable, but this? Get it at half off or better. It's that good. (Rising Tide is a must-have with this, so only consider getting BE if you can bundle it.)

184368863.review:
You will more than likely need to follow some version of the instructions for getting it to run, but I do love this game and have had it forever.

These are the steps that worked for me:

- clean install BE (uninstall via Steam then delete the folder in steamapps, reinstall)
- close Steam, run Steam as admin
- Right click and edit properties of CivilizationBE_DX11 in game files ( \SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\ )
	- on the Compatibility tab:
		• Check 'Disable fullscreen optimizations'
		• Check 'run this program as admin'
		• Check 'Compatibility mode' & set to Windows 8
- Double-click CivilizationBE_DX11 to launch the program
	(the original instructions said to run via the command window, but the prompt denied the existence of said file)
- BE will launch itself, get past the updating .exe, then not open
	• !!! Emphasis on the fact that it will not run !!!
	• In my case, it also appeared to 'delete' the .exe and it moved to the bottom of the folder
- Go back to properties of CivilizationBE_DX11 and uncheck 'Compatibility mode'
- Launch BE via Steam

184269470.review: Game no longer launches after a recent update. Again. If I could ask for a refund, I would, because this is just silly.

184170397.review:
I enjoyed the game very much, though I recently noticed that the game won't boot.

After some tinkering, I've found a reliable solution:

1. Install the game.
2. Right click on the game in the Steam Library and select Manage -> Browse Local Files.
3. Once the File Explorer opens, go one step up, so you can see the main game folder. Should be in "***\Steam\steamapps\common\".
4. Right click the "Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth" folder and select Properties.
5. Untick Read-Only (apply it to subfolders and subfiles as well).
6. Once done - boot the game.

It is possible the game STILL won't run, but that's okay because:

7. Repeat step 4-6. In the install folder, right under the CivilizationBE_DX11.exe file, Steam may create a file with a weird name (civilizationbe_dx11.exe.4328.STEAMSTART). Delete that file and boot the game again. This time, Steam should properly be able to update the game files and the game should boot normally.

Once it boots up once, these steps should no longer be necessary.

This solution worked on a couple of different machines/setups so far, so I'm positive it should work for you as well!

Time to go Beyond Earth!

184118483.review: Es macht einfach Spass, und man kann es sehr oft Spielen ohne sich zu langweilen.

184078494.review:
This is my favorite Civ game. Is it perfect, absolutley not, but there is something about the Sci-Fi setting and the affinity system that lets you choose how your people adapt to their new world that I find undeniably charming. As a matter of fact when I got my first "modern" gaming PC in 2017, this was the first game I was dying to play because I couldn't meet the settings on my family's old computer.

So, what is the game? Essentially, Earth is dying and you pick from one of the several factions that manage to leave Earth to colonize a new planet. And once you're there, you set up shop and decide how you intend to progress as one of the last bastions of humanity. Do you adapt and synergize with the local flora and fauna? Augment yourselves with cybernetics and drones? Or build mechs and try to recreate the Earth that you lost? These ideas are what I love most about the game, and with the Rising Tide dlc, which I would consider mandatory btw, it introduces aquatic floating cities, hybrid affinities and some new sponsors.

There have been several people that say that the game no longer launches, and I was having that issue on Windows 11 for a long time until I found a workaround, here's what I did:
Right click on the game in your library, go to local files and hit browse, find the file that says Civilization BE DX11 and right click on it, hit properties, go to compatibility, where it says what Windows OS you're using select "Windows 7" and tic the box for "Run as Administrator", then Apply settings and you should be good to go.

I think this game deserves a lot of love and I hope someone remakes it someday because it genuinely had some great potential and I have a lot of good memories associated with it. :  )
